Prologue

Paradise Island

Day of Judgement



The radiance of the morning was blocked from view by a distinctly unnatural eclipse, a dark and terrible shadow falling across the landscape all the way to the horizon, large enough to swallow up a dozen towns. With a deafening rumble like thunder another cityscape was reduced to dust, the tortured screams of unaccountable thousands echoing across the landscape. From the point of impact, a tidal wave of pressurized dust and debris swept outwards in all directions, smashing down any surviving structures in its wake for miles around in every direction.

Soaringly high above the shattered remains of the ruined principality towered an object of such immense size it was unperceivable to the tiny handful of battered survivors who found themselves closest to it. At best they could perceive two vast mountains of obsidian black rock towering above the horizon, though they had no idea that what they saw were merely the twin tips of something much more massive. Those further away who had the benefit of distance and scale could see the massive construct for what it truly was, the dual toes of a gigantic boot, armoured yet distinctly feminine, and unmistakably alien. A second boot, identical to the first was poised across the river that marked the boundary of that particular territorial district, the smouldering ruins of a once prosperous trading town strewn around it. From the base of each foot soared an almost metallic cylinder like tower of silver and black, each of which gave way to the outline of a colossal and shapely thigh wrapped in synthetic black webbing and cloth several thousand meters above. Dizzyingly high above the skyline, elaborately curved and interlocking plates of metallic silver combined with a synthetic bodysuit drawn tightly over corded muscles and flesh, forming the silhouette of a gigantic alien woman clad in a suit of distinctly extra-terrestrial environmental armour. Her face was hidden behind a reflective half oval faceplate, whilst a vast cowl covered the metallic helmet that enclosed the head behind her mask, the hood reaching down to the woman's shoulders.

The giantess was truly monolithic in stature.

The gigantic Quarian paused, the gauntlets of her colossal three fingered hands resting atop her hips as she surveyed the land below, the crushed out remains of the towns and cities she had already visited that morning splotched out as tiny imperfections to the rolling hills and plains of this world. Sunlight from a distant star glanced off her breastplate and helm as the alien woman cast her eyes over the sprawling landscape, her featureless mask bereft of any emotion as all around her, the world burned.

Small arms and cannon fire shrieked upwards at the giantess from seemingly every direction, the explosive shells and projectiles disintegrating harmlessly against her cyclonic energy shielding. Blue lighting continued to crackle and spit around her, the tiny humanoids who still found themselves closest to her shrieking as the electrical discharge of her shielding lashed out, vaporizing them to ash. Almost by subconscious afterthought the woman’s hand strayed to the pistol at her hip, her gloved forefinger deftly brushing over the trigger before she thought better of it. Nothing on this world could harm her, and it would not have been worth the effort to visit such disproportionate destruction upon the indigenous inhabitants at this time.

In the distance wherever she looked, the Quarian woman saw destruction and calamity of a truly catastrophic scale. The smallest of this world’s indigenous inhabitants reminded her, at least ‘superficially’ of the humans she had known of and met in what now seemed a distant previous life, before she had become stranded upon this world. Baring herself of course, they were clearly the most intelligent inhabitants of this world, and they still fought to defend a civilization that had in reality already fallen. Their walls breached and their population centres exposed to the raving depravations of their lumbering almost zombie like kin who dwarfed them in size and scale many times over, the inhabitants of the island kingdom still fought on. Their soldiers formed barricades and blockades behind guns and artillery when they could, herding their civilian population to the safety of walled enclosures where such structures still existed. The Quarian watched them firing their weapons at both the diminutive ‘titans’ as she had come to call them, and herself, her shielding still vaporizing every projectile and shell that was fired at her in pathetic puffs of tiny smoke.

The Quarian woman knew that she was responsible for the nightmarish hellscape this previously idyllic paradise had become, and she knew there was nothing she could do to stop the coming extermination had she even been inclined to. Whether they died in the bloodstained maws of the encroaching titans that looked so much like them or were pulverized to death beneath her own colossal steps, the Quarian knew that the indigenous ‘humans’ of this island simply would not survive. Not now the last of their defences had been overrun.

But she still could, with what lied at their very heart of their island and kingdom. With that thought in her mind the Quarian continued her path of unfathomable destruction across the kingdom, the sprawling urban city that was this human kingdom’s capital quickly appearing upon the horizon.

The Quarian woman’s foot came down just outside the outskirts of the capital city. Her armoured boot straddled a vast highway that led to the ‘mighty’ metropolis’s centre, the city’s walls and multi-storied building situated upon its outskirts shaking with the force of her footfall, their slopped roofs not even reaching the height of her toes. From the vantage point of her visor distantly high above, the woman glimpsed movement in the shadows cast beneath her boots, scores of tiny humans fleeing in terror towards the imagined safety of their capital.

From her vantage point, the Quarian woman could see the city had already all but fallen.

Titans in such vast numbers that she had not encountered before thronged the city, the clumsy giants smashing their way through buildings and thoroughfares as they clawed at and feasted upon the fleeing humans by their hundreds. The sharp crackle of many hundreds of rifles and small arms fire, interspaced with heavier cannon blasts and explosions ripped across the city’s skyline, indicating remnants of the cities garrison still remained. Many thousands of humans still remained within the city despite the titan infestation.

They would not remain alive much longer.

Rifles and cannons continued to pepper the Quarian giantess with sporadic fire, her shielding disintegrating the tiny projectiles with ease. With surreal and almost leisurely grace the Quarian raised her hand towards the city, small arms fire and explosive munitions exploding harmlessly against the heavy leather of her palm. Turning her hand over, the Quarian flex her long fingers and thumb before activating her Omni-tool, her eyes scanning the data that appeared before her.

There was no mistake, the transmission was originating from beneath the city’s centre.

With a tired sigh the Quarian deactivated her Omni-tool, her colossal three fingered hands descending to her hips as she lifted her foot from the ground. Raw clumps of earth and asphalt from the despoiled ground below tumbled free from her bootsole as she lifted her foot above the city, her leg bent at the knee. Beneath her in the carnage of the capital’s streets, tiny human and colossal titans alike suddenly looked upwards as the dark shadow of her foot swept over them, hundreds of tiny humans falling to their knees in fear, terror and prostration. Men, women and children screamed in terror, clutched and their loved ones and begged for their lives as dizzyingly high above and with her hands poised atop her shapely hips, the Quarian woman’s expressionless mask looked down at them between the dual tips of her toes, her cold intentions towards them unmistakable.

She was gigantic, an impossibly huge titan towering above titans.

Her soon to be victims could only pray as the Quarian made her final judgement;

The Quarian giantess stood, somewhere between;
1.title: Prologue - Day of Judgement

11.content:
Chapter 0-1

24 Hours Earlier

Paradise Island

Fall of Shiganshina District (Wall Maria)


Fear, as powerful as it was raw hung over the human district of Shiganshina, southern most outpost of the kingdom that existed within the three walls.

Every street, alleyway and public space that was crammed into the modest outlier town was silent, the very human stench of terror chocking the throats of every single citizen who resided within that tiny pocket of humanity. All eyes were raised to the fifty metre high wall and the skinless yet very human like head that soared above it, a dark and unnatural shadow protruding across the centre of the district as the titan; colossal beyond all reckoning looked down upon the little humans with hunger.

Alex stared up at the giant’s head, his lips parted and mouth dry in the summer heat of the afternoon, the boy’s tongue stubbornly still and unmoving inside his mouth.

“Oh God…”

“It’s…it’s a titan” Sara whispered from behind him, the hand of his adopted sister clasped around his, her nails digging into his palm.

Movement flickered at the corner of his eye, and instinctively Alex knew that one of their two younger siblings was beside them.

Was it Billy, or Jessica?

Alex could not turn his head to see, so thawed with fear the young boy was.

Scarcely a minute before, the four young siblings had all been happy and laughing, the children enjoying the afternoon sunshine which had seen them relaxing in the central plaza of Shiganshina district.

They were homeless street orphans all of them, related neither by blood, marriage or money, but instead by the need of young children to find solace and comfort in a society that had all but abandoned them. Alex was the oldest of them at twelve years of age, with Sara the older ‘sister’ of the group at ten. Billy was eight, and Jessica six. They looked out for each other, protected each other, and together the four siblings formed a close knit family that survived together in the poorest region of the kingdom behind the walls.

That momentary happiness between the hunger, the freezing nights spent upon cold city streets and hiding from corrupt soldiers of the city garrison seemed a distant dream in Alex’s past now as the huge face of the titan looked down upon them.

“That’s…not possible…” Billy stammered, “…that wall is over fifty metres tall. That titan’s got to be…”

“Over Two Hundred feet high” Alex finished.

“Is that a titan?” Jessica asked, her voice as innocently naïve as it always was.

“We have to get out of…”

Before Alex could finish a thunderous crash shook the district, Wall Maria seeming to groan with the sound of cracking rock as the ground shook beneath the four children’s feet, and then the centre of the curtain wall was smashed outwards in a churning explosion of dust and debris.

Alex was suddenly snapped from his stupor. Grasping his siblings by their arms he dragged them towards the nearest building as chucks of the broken wall peppered the city. Slabs of stone and mortar smashed through buildings, flattened houses and peppered streets, cutting down and crushing anyone unfortunate enough to find themselves in their path.

Blood splashed across the cobbled streets and walls as the first screams echoed across the district, fear giving way to panic as the full realization of what had just happened dawned upon the little township’s inhabitants.

“Their though the walls!” someone screamed.

As he was helping Billy to his feet, Alex turned towards wall, his gut twisting like a knife inside his stomach. Wall Maria still stood, the Colossal Titan suddenly gone as quickly as it had appeared, but from the gaping hole it had smashed through the lower segment of the wall, lanky and pale humanoid forms many times taller than a man were emerging, gapping wide toothed mouths open atop bobbing listing heads, their swollen human like eyes searching hungrily for flesh.

Titans!

“We’ve got to get to the gate” Alex shouted, grasping Jessica’s arm as he did so, “Sara, take Billy’s hand. Don’t let go.”

“We’ve got no papers” Sara cried, “They won’t let us through.”

“We’ve got to try. Come On!”

Together, the four orphans sprinted across the open plaza, a large crowd already forming across the mouth of the Aquila thoroughfare, the most direct route to the only remaining gate out of Shiganshina District, and deeper into the Kingdom behind the Walls.

As they approached the avenue, just how hopeless their situation was becoming apparent to Alex very quickly. Shiganshina District contained over ten thousand permanently resident men, women and children, and it seemed that every single one of them today was gathered into a single swelling crowd that blocked the main intersection of the thoroughfare, their numbers growing with every passing second.

A thin line of city guardsmen from the Royal Garrison were clustered around the baying mob, their distinctive mustard brown overcoats marking them out amongst the crowd. Futilely they tried to bring some semblance of order to chaotic crowd, the militiamen burnishing their antiquated flint-lock muskets and firelocks into the air.

It was just as Alex and his three siblings reached the edge of the crowd that the sound of crumbling brick and masonry echoed across the open plaza. Panting for breath Alex turned, his three siblings pausing to follow his gaze towards the other end of the square, just in time to see a titan clambering over a triple storied house.

The titan was perhaps five or six metres tall, its giant form lurching drunkenly forward as it tried to navigate its way over the house, one long leg coming down upon the buildings balcony. The was a grinding off broken tiles and then suddenly the titan was plunging through the second storey roof, its arms flailing uselessly as it tried to dig its way free, and then the second titan appeared.

It was at least twice as tall of the first, and unlike its companion it emerged from the closest street, a third titan stumbling forth in its wake. More titans suddenly appeared, their slow unwieldy forms rising from behind the row of houses and shops that lined the plaza and adjacent roads, roofs and walls, an overhanging bridge collapsing as one smashed its way into the plaza, the tallest amongst them standing over fourteen metres high.

“There in the square!” someone shouted.

“Guardsman” shouted a thick voice, “Form Up. Deploy the cannons!”

A line of guardsmen detached themselves from the crowd, running past Alex, Sara, Billy and Jessica as they stormed into the square. The thick tubular barrels of half a dozen serpentine cannons upon wooden carts were pulled out with them, the guardsmen forming a line about a hundred strong as they levelled their muskets and cannons towards the approaching titans. A thickly build man in a sergeants uniform emerged from their ranks. The man sported a curling moustache, and burnished a sword which he now swept through the air.

“Fire!” the sergeant screamed.

Alex clasped his hands over his ears, shouting at his siblings to do the same as the first volley fired, the whistling crack of close to a hundred muskets suddenly followed by explosive boom as the cannons let loose, the wheels of their carriages lurching backwards with the force of the blast.

The shots slammed into the oncoming titans, the pee sixed musket balls peppering their wiry misshapen bodies as the cannon shots ripped through limbs, human like blood splashing across the plaza floor. Alex saw a titan stumble and fall, its nightmarish face reduced to a bloody stump where one of the cannons had caught its head and ripped it clean off, but to his horror Alex could see its body already fighting to regain its footing, a twisting mass of flesh atop its neck already reforming as it head began to grow back.

No more than two of the titans had been felled by the solders first volley, and at least a dozen more were already shambling forwards, the closest halfway across the square already.

“Reload” the sergeant shouted, “Protect the civilians at all costs.”

The soldiers fired again, and the lead titan was cut down, but then another was shambling forwards in its place, its ten-metre-high form towering above the thin line of soldiers who were still reloading.

“What do we do!” Sara screamed from behind Alex, “We’re trapped.”

Alex turned back to the crowd, his heart sinking. Without the guardsmen there to police the evacuation, the crowd that still blocked the intersection had descended into an even more chaotic mass as people punched, kicked and clawed at each other, the press of so many human bodies preventing all but a handful from moving forward. Already Alex could see more titans worming their way around the plazas edge, and instinctively he knew they intended to flank the soldiers. The dumb brute’s tiny animal like minds had deduced the quickest possible path to the crowd.

That intersection would soon become a bloodbath.

“Alex!” Sara screamed, Jessica and Billy crying behind her “What do we do?”
11.title: 1 MT - Chapter 1 - Fall of Shiganshina

111.content:
“Follow me” Alex shouted. Leading Jessica again by her arm, Alex sprinted across the edge of square, Sara and Billy hard on his heels. Steeling a glance over his shoulder, Alex glimpsed a titan in amongst detachment of soldiers. Their line reeled, a squirming human form suspended at least eight metres off the ground in the meaty fist of a titan. The soldier convulsed inside the titan’s fist as the fingers of the giant crushed his torso, blood frothing from the man’s lips as his companions fired their muskets upwards.

Alex twisted back his head, swerving to avoid a discarded box of rotting fish. Jessica cried out as her foot struck the box, but Alex continued to pull her after him, ignoring his baby sisters whimpering.

Rather than the intersection, Alex led them to one of the plaza’s corners, where the sewage of the both Shiganshina eastern and northern drainage ditches met in a low slung trench. Jumping into the filthy knee deep water Alex grasped hold of the thin grated wire-mesh plate that blocked the entrance to the underground pipe and pulled with all his might.

The plate groaned, one edge peeling free from the waterproof brickwork to which it was stuck. The thin wire-mesh twisted between his fingers, blood dripping from between his nails, then with one last groan the thinly stripped metal came apart, the grated plate coming out in his hands.

“It’s open” Alex said, “Come on, get in. Get in!”

Sara was the first in, dragging a now sobbing Jessica behind her as the two girls descended to their knees and disappeared into the pipe. Billy was next, Alex pushing his younger brother into the pipe with both hands before turning back to the square, the water suddenly trembling around him.

Turning back towards the plaza, Alex’s heart sunk. At least a dozen titans were now amongst the guardsmen, and almost each and every one of the giant freaks had the limbs of a screaming and struggling soldier clasped in their huge hands, obvious to the scattered musket fire tearing into their flesh as they feasted upon their screaming, still living victims.

A titan chased a fleeing soldier, the man dropping his spent musket only to be plucked from the ground, kicking at the thick meaty fingers that had grasped hold of his leg. His screams echoed across the square as the titan clamped its huge mouth around his torso, thick arterial blood spurting upwards. A cannon fired, blowing the arm of another titan clean off as its crew tried to reload, then another titan was upon them, overturning the cannon and crushing one of the surviving soldiers, one of his companions hurriedly reloading his musket as another fled.

Movement from the corner of his eyes caught Alex attention, and suddenly the young boy realized a titan was lumbering towards him, the water splashing upwards around his legs. It was a big titan, almost fifteen metres tall, and it was almost upon him.

Diving to his knees Alex scrambled into the pipeway. From the corner of his eye his glimpsed one final shot of the plaza, the human soldiers dead or dying, the crowd at the intersection all but clawing over each other as the titans converged upon them, a towering fifteen metre tall titan plucking a man from the crowd to consume. And then there was the human sergeant in the middle of plaza, his sword still brandished into the air and hand-musket grasped in one hand, surrounded.

The approaching titan stumbled and fell, its clumsy flailing body landing straight atop the trench. Already in the pipe, a sudden surge of water splashed over Alex, the filthy liquid getting into his eyes, ears and mouth. Still the boy continued forward, the repetitive splash splash splash up ahead telling him that his siblings were still clambering through the tunnel further up.

“Keep going” Alex screamed spitting out the fowl tasting water as he did so, “Don’t stop.”

It was many minutes later that they reached the other end of the pipe, Sara poised at the entrance waiting for Alex while Billy and Jessica sat shivering in the closest alleyway.

Human screams, alongside the sound of ripping flesh and breaking bones echoed across the rooftops, coming from where the crowd had been at the edge of the plaza.

“We’ve got to keep moving” Alex said, rousing Billy and Jessica to their feet, “Get up get up. They’ll be closing the gate soon.”

The children were now on Shiganshina District’s northern side, only a few streets to the gateway. Hand in hand Alex led them forward, the four orphans emerging from the alleyway and into a small square, the ground suddenly shaking.

A titan emerged from atop the overhanging roofs, its towering form at least ten metres high. Its wide mouthed grinning visage regarded the young orphans with hunger, and suddenly one gangly arm was reaching down towards them.

“Run!” Alex shouted, pushing his siblings to one side. Together they dived under an overhanging archway, the titan half destroying the front of a shop was its attempt to grasp at them went wide.

Twisting on his heel Alex shoved Jessica and Billy forward, Sara running behind him and together the siblings sprinted beneath the titan’s legs, the massive creature twisting it body to fast as it stumbled and fell.

The ground shook with the giant’s collapse. Billy cried out as he stumbled forward, but Alex was behind him, pushing his younger brother to his feet.

They emerged from the alleyway into the main thoroughfare, two mid-sized titans turning to meet them.

“Back” Alex shouted, the titan’s arms coming up as they stumbled forwards, preparing to grasp at the human children, “Get back!”

Cannon fire ripped across the thoroughfare, smashing straight into the two titans. One of the titans took a cannon ball straight to the shoulder, the blast ripping apart half its torso whilst the second took a blow to its legs, the shot ripping them both clean off as thick arterial human like blood splashed across the walls and street.

Glancing the way the shots had come, Alex could see the inner gate. Six cannons and a gaggle of guardsman were gathered around the gate’s entrance, waving the children forwards.

“It’s still open” Alex said, pulling Jessica and Billy into the street, “Come on. Run!”

They entered the thoroughfare, Alex and Sara each dragging one of their younger siblings after them. From the closest alleyways and streets other humans emerged, and soon they were part of small crowd filtering up the gate. The familiar sound of crumbling bricks and mortar echoed down the road.

Glancing over his shoulder as he ran, Alex saw a titan emerge from the thoroughfare’s winding edge, at least two more behind it.

“Get down” a soldier screamed, Alex and Sara throwing their younger siblings to the ground as the cannons fired. The Oncoming titan was cut down as were two of the beast’s companions. Alex twisted onto his back as the gigantic humanoids stumbled forwards and fell, limbs and heads ripped clean off, but already he could see movement behind them.

“Get up, get up!” he said, rousing Jessica to her feet. The girl continued to sob as they pushed forward, Sara and Billy behind them, and then they were at the gate. A blond haired officer shoved them through the gigantic archway beneath the interior of wall Maria, and then suddenly for the first time in their lives Alex, Sara, Billy and Jessica were outside of Shiganshina district, and inside the interior of Wall Maria.

A vast expanse of open green fields and rolling hills stretched out as far as any of them could see, whilst a cobbled road and water canal from the gateway ran all the way to the horizon. Somewhere far in the distance Alex knew Wall Rose stood, and beyond that Wall Sheena, and then the royal capital and the lavish Palace of the King.

Another crowd greeted them, even larger than the one they had encountered in the plaza. The mass of huddled refugees from Shiganshina District was nestled between the small trading outpost that adjoined Wall Maria’s Inner Gate, and a makeshift port where a line of Gondola’s were docked. A thin line of guardsman was gathered before the ships, selecting people to take on and turning others away, their flintlock muskets pointed towards the crowd as a warning.

“There” Alex said, “Come on. We have to get on that last ship.”

A sharp crack of cannon fire echoed from inside the gate as they approached the port, the crowd and soldiers tensing, yet no one tried to rush the boats. Alex and his siblings made their way through the press of the crowd, Alex maintaining a firm grip on Jessica’s hand, who in turn had her hand gripped to Jesscia’s, who in turn was leading Billy at their rear.

Behind them another volley of cannon and musket fire boomed, people glancing nervously back the way they had come.

“Come on!” someone shouted up ahead, “Let us on!”

“Women and children only at this time Sir” a reply came, “More Gondola’s will be here soon for the rest of you.”

They reached the front of the crowd just as another volley of cannon fire went off, the thin line of soldiers stretched out before the docked ships eying each other nervously as the crowd edged closer, then a man attempted to rush the nearest gangplank.

“Stop him!” an officer shouted.

Two soldiers leapt forward to restrain the man, their compatriots raising their muskets to the crowd in warning.
111.title: 1 MT - Chapter 1 - Fall of Shiganshina - Part II

1111.content:
“There” Alex gestured, pointing towards the nearest Gondola. Together the four children made their way forward, a shaven headed officer glancing up and waving them forward, his soldiers parting to let them on.

They were just at the gangplank of the nearest ship when a forth volley of cannon and musket fire echoed outwards from behind Wall Rose, this time the gunfire punctuated with a chorus of human screams. Alex turned his head, glimpsing the terrified looks on the faces of the crowd, and then the first scream went up.

“There right outside the gate!”

With that the crowd finally panicked and surged, dozens of people pushing their way forward as a soldier discharged his musket into the crowd, then all hell broke loose. Hundreds of Shiganshina’s townspeople were surging up the gang plank, the half a dozen or so soldiers guarding it being grappled to the ground and beaten as more muskets were fired into the roaring crowd.

Alex pulled Sara behind him, Jessica trying to do the same to Billy as the crowd surged into them, and then suddenly Alex was falling, thick hands grasping him by his collar and throwing him aside and back onto the dry-docks ledge

“Sara”, Alex shouted, “Jessica!”

In the thick press of bodies Alex glimpsed Billy, his younger brother tossed to the ground the other side of the gang plank, struggling to return to his feet.

He couldn’t see his sisters.

“Cast off, cast off. Before they swamp us” a voice screamed.

The Gondola suddenly lurched precariously to one side, over a hundred people screaming as they were thrown from the tumbling gangplank. A handful of them were able to grasp onto the rails of the ship as it began to cast off, those onboard struggling to pull them to safety however the majority tumbled downwards, splashing into the water below.

Through the press of people, Alex glimpsed Sara and Jessica, the two girls staring back at them from the Gondola’s wooden deck.

They were safe, for now.

The other Gondola’s were preparing to cast off, the crews and passengers upending the gangplanks even as people continued to try and board them, hundreds of screaming refuges splashing into the cold water off the dry dock below.

Glancing back towards the trading centre across the road, Alex caught sight of a dozen wagons and horses, a ring of armed mercenaries holding back a smaller crowd just as the soldiers before the Gondola’s had been a moment earlier.

Scrambling back to his feet, Alex found his way to Billy and pulled the young boy to his feet.

“What do we do” his brother cried.

“Follow me.”

Alex led his brother across the road and past the trading centre, another round of cannon fire punctuating the screams of both crowds.

Alex and Billy wormed their way through the crowd and were soon within sight of the wagons. Whoever owned the caravan must have had a soft spot for the two orphans that day, for the ring of guards parted and they were dragged forward, the crowd yelling and clawing behind them.

“What about us!” someone screamed.

A tall mercenary with cropped black hair lifted Alex and Billy into one of the caravan’s, the rear compartment so crammed with women, children and a small number of labourers that the two boys were forced to perch themselves upon the end, their legs dangling over the wagons parapet.

“That’s it, time to go!” the caravan master shouted, and with that the drivers lashed their horses into action, the towering animals snorting as they began to trot forward, pulling the lumbering wheeled carts behind them. The mercenaries rushed back towards their caravans as the crowd surged after them, the caravan picking up speed as they boarded each of the wagons in turn, their fellow guards hanging from the carts edges to beat off the questing hands of the crowd with heavy truncheons.

Alex didn’t think that they would make it out of the mob, but at the last moment the bulk of the crowd dispersed before the now charging horses, the few remaining men and women being trampled down by the heavy draft horses as they passed.

It was with a mixture of both relief and fatigue that Alex allowed himself to fall backwards onto the caravans wooden floor.

In the distance, the Gondola carrying Sara and Jessica receded towards the horizon, no doubt on its way to Trost District.

They would be safe there, until Alex and Billy caught up with them.

“Is it over” Billy asked.

“I think so” Alex replied, “We’re safe now.”

The Inner Gateway of Shiganshina District was just barely visible to them now, but Alex could see the gate coming down. They would close it, the titans would not follow and despite the hundreds of people who had died here today, that would be that.

It was only a handful of seconds later that both boys saw the Inner gateway smash outwards, a fifteen-metre-tall armoured titan barrelling straight through the archway as if it had been made of sand.

It had finally happened.

The titans had breached wall Maria.
1111.title: 1 MT - Chapter 1 - Fall of Shiganshina - Part III

11111.content:
The Quarian woman awoke to the unmistakable taste of blood upon her lips.

She was lying on her back; her legs crossed one over the other, and her arms prone at her side.

Faintly, the Quarian could just make out the faint trickle of water as she moved her head, the cool liquid gently splashing beneath her shoulders and the supple cheeks of her ass as she gently flexed her muscles.

Even through the dense padding of her armoured environmental suit, the water was still a pleasant sensation to wake up to, until she was aware of the sudden bleeping warning beacon screaming in her ear.

The Quarian opened her eyes to a small army of hazard runes flashing across the heads-up display of her helmets violet tinted visor, momentarily perplexed by what they meant. Deftly she recognized the symbol for foreign contaminant but could not recall what she was suppose to do until she felt the medical antibodies administered by her suit flooding into her bloodstream.

Deep down at the back of her throat the Quarian could feel something begin to bubble and froth, and suddenly she knew she was about to be sick.

Pushing herself up onto one elbow the female shuddered, clenching her lips more out of reflex then actual conscious thought. Water trickled down from her back, small waves rippling forth in the water around her as she reached towards the Omni-tool at her wrist with her free hand, her gloved finger and thumb activating her suits environmental controls.

She coughed, her lips still clenched tightly behind gritted teeth, and with one final flick of her thumb she stabbed down at her Omni-tool, overriding the emergency ventilation port of her helmet. The cylindrical port which covered her mouth opened with a pressurised hiss, her lips parted and she vomited.

“Ooogggg…”

Blood, bile and a toxic mixture of broken down antibiotic paste plummeted down into the water below. The Quarian heaved again, her hand splashing down into the water, and faintly was she aware of the ground crumbling beneath her gloved palm, almost as if she had been a giant slamming her fist into the ground.

Just as quickly had the sensation to gag had come over her, it passed.

Clean filtered air fed by her suit pumped into her helmet and with a smooth gust of wind her mouth port closed, sealing her back inside her helmet. She breathed, a sensation of weightlessness momentarily overcoming her as a second round of antibiotics and endorphins flood through her bloodstream, purging any remnants of the contaminants which appeared to have temporarily breached her suit.

Groggily, the Quarian woman sat up, one hand still planted firmly behind her. Drawing her long legs up towards her chest, she flexed the toes of her boots and once she was satisfied she was reasonably stable, she tried to stand.

The movement of rising to her feet was relatively fluid, through she still felt a little unsteady. Perplexingly, she felt her boots sink slightly into the ground. It was not the sensation of her feet sinking into sand, but the impression of a million tiny fragments of shale crushing like ice beneath her bootsoles, yet whatever the strange substance she was standing on was, it seemed to support her weight.

The Quarian found herself looking at her hand, her long fingers and thumb flexing beneath the heavy padding of her suit’s gloves.

“Who am I…?” the Quarian asked, her voice coming out as a metallic echo of the one she imagined hearing in her head.

Suddenly she found herself looking towards the horizon, the endless puddle of water seemingly to stretch around her in all directions.

“Where am I…?”

Neither question answered the other, though she could sense her name of the very tip of her tongue, and slowly memories began to resurface.

She titled her head towards the sky, the sunlight glancing of her visor.

It was bright, unusually bright and she was forced to lift a hand to shield her eyes.

Up there, beyond the blue sky of this world and into the dark blackness beyond was where she had come from.

She was a Quarian. Her people were a nomadic race of scavengers, engineers and scientists, forever doomed to travel the endless void of space within their sealed starships, to be sneered and loathed by those races and civilizations who still enjoyed the protection of their colonies and homeworlds. Somewhere deep down the Quarian knew that she despised them for that, and in her deepest darkest thoughts she sometimes found herself wishing unspeakable calamity upon those ignorant people and races. A dark shadow falling across the civilization of those who had never known hunger or loss, the tiny aliens fleeing as a boot of cruel malice ground them beneath its heel.

Her immune system was weak. That much she remembered clearly, hence the need for her sealed environmental suit, yet stubbornly her name and her personnel history escaped her.

Lowering her head, the Quarian glanced back towards the horizon. Her hands descended to her hips as she surveyed her surroundings, trying to make sense at what she saw.

There was no beach, no landmass, and yet she knew she could not have been standing in the middle of an ocean with the water lapping around her boots.

“Hmmmm…” the Quarian mused, “Could I be a giant…?”

She imagined tiny wooden sailing ships banking against the crushing waves beneath her ankles, the minuscule human like crews fighting against their rigging as she stepped backwards, oblivious to their presence even as she condemned them and their tiny wooden sailing ships to be crushed beneath her hard soles of her boots.

The idea was entertaining, if only for a moment, but quite preposterous.

She was woman of science, and therefore she knew that there must a reasonable explanation for the world she found herself on.

Almost as if it had been in response to the thought, she glimpsed something ahead, just below the horizon. Her visor dimmed to compensate for the intense light, and suddenly she could see a landmass ahead.

The Quarian could have slapped a palm to her visor.

It was right there!

How by the God’s could she have missed it?

The landmass was shallow but she was sure that was just an effect of the light blocking her full view of the horizon and the mountains that would be beyond.

Just as she was about to set off towards it, her Omni-tool bleeped.

Turning to the holographic terminal across her wrist, the Quarian tapped at the interface, her eyebrow rising in an almost quizzical gesture. Somewhere in the direction of the ‘island’ was a signal, perhaps a way for her to get off this world and back to the flotilla.

Either way, it was better than staying here.

Smiling beneath her helmet, the Quarian took her first step towards the island. Water rippled outwards in tandems with her footfalls, and as she got closer more and more of the island could be seen.

It was surprisingly flat from what she could see, but as more and more of the landmass came into focus she saw what might have been larger landmarks against the horizon.

Or was it just a trick of her eyes?

The Quarian woman was half way to setting foot on ‘Paradise Island’, and the besieged Kingdom behind the Walls when suddenly she remembered her name, and who she was;

- Her Name was;

Chapter 0-1-1-1


The sun of this world was uncomfortably bright.

Tali’Zorah nar Rayya paused to lift a gloved hand to the oval visor of her helmet, shielding her eyes from the glare of sunlight that glimmered high overhead.

There was something ahead, she was sure of it.

Tali had been walking now for over an hour.

Her feet were aching, and until now she had encountered no signs of civilization. This ‘island’ was just as peculiar as the manner in which Tali had first awoken to find herself upon this world in the first place.

It had not taken her long at all to reach the island, yet when she arrived at its edge there had been no beach, simply a thin ‘boundary’ of sand which marked where the water ended and the island began. The landmass of the island itself was a soupy green marsh of flatland save for a few gently sloping inclines and mounds, pleasing to look at but so soft and yielding that Tali’s boots had sunk almost to her ankles when she had stepped into it.

Indeed, the Quarian was starting to believe rather half-heartedly that she really was a giant on this world.

Tali had continued on, tiny clumps of wet marsh and soil falling free from her bootsoles with each and every step she took. Her Omni-tool had taken her deeper and deeper into the island’s centre as it had continued to pinpoint the mysterious signal’s location.

It was now, with her raised hand shielding her eyes from the overbearing sun that Tali glimpsed her first possible sign of civilization.

It was a wall!

A wall that just barely surpassed the height of the Quarian woman’s ankles.

At first Tali thought it was natural structure, perhaps a tiny outcropping of rock that had become sandwiched into the surrounding marshland, but as she approached the edifice she knew this could not be the case.

Tali’s foot came down just in front of the ‘wall’, and with dexterous caution she knelt down, running her eyes over the miniature structure. It was constructed from stone and stood perhaps five full centimetres high, its length dotted with tiny and almost adorable watchtowers and other fortifications.

It extended outwards in both directions, as far as Tali’s eyes could see even with the magnification her helmet offered.

Her curiosity momentarily getting the better of her, Tali reached down and ran an experimental finger along the walls top. Her gloved fingertip quickly came into contact with one of the wall’s stone watchtowers, the building suddenly toppling in a miniature avalanche of dissolving stonework as her fingertip smashed right through it, all bit obliterating the tower in the process.

Tali withdrew her hand as if stung, suddenly conscious that she had damaged the wall.

It had been like touching a little child’s sandcastle.

She had not expected it to be so…fragile!

“Is this a toy” Tali mused, glancing back up and down the length of the wall, and the expanse of the island’s landmass that surrounded it.

Was this entire island, this entire world nothing more than some rich brat’s playground, populated with miniature landscapes and structures?

Tali slowly rose back to her full height, dusting of her hands as she did so.

It didn’t matter one way or the other.

What mattered was finding a way off this planet, and the signal her Omni-tool was leading her to may provide just such an avenue.

Twisting on her heel Tali stepped over the wall, the mile tall quarrian unknowingly taking her first step into the humanlike kingdom of Eldia.

In an act of pure spite Tali dragged her other foot forward, the twin toes of her boot deliberately smashing straight into the wall in an explosion of crumbling masonry and stone that saw an entire section of the wall crumble, dust and debris raining down into the surrounding marshland.

Tali pretended not to notice the damage she had caused as she strode off, but if this planet really was the fantasy made real of a family with more money than sense, then she had just made her feeling on the matter very clear.

Unfortunately, Tali’Zorah nar Rayya didn’t realize that the wall she had just smashed open was all that protected the native citizens of Eldia from the ravenous titans, and that she had just allowed those same titans to pour into the kingdom unchallenged in her wake.

“More Titans!” a woman screamed.

It had been many hours since the caravan of mule driven wagons had escaped Shiganshina district, and this had been their third encounter with titans in the last hour alone.

Alex and Billy were still poised upon the rear ledge of their wagon, and they had been amongst the first to spot the latest wave of giant humanoids that precipitated the woman’s scream.

Perhaps half a mile to the east where a line of trees marked the edge of a communal farm, Alex glimpsed the telltale bobbing heads of the oncoming titans over the tree line.

There were at least a dozen of them, the rising sun throwing out long and terrible shadows as they stumbled towards the fleeing wagons.

“Shit!” the caravan master cursed, the tall moustached man clambering up to the top of the wagon to get a better look.

“Relax everyone” he shouted, “with the horses, we’re faster than them.”

With a snap of his fingers the caravan master gestured down towards the lead wagon driver at the front of the caravan.

“Jenkins, take a right at this next pass, I see a farm coming up. Let’s get some buildings between us and those freaks to cut off their line of sight. We should be fine anyway but let’s not take chances.”

“Aye Boss, you got it.” the wagon driver, this ‘Jenkins’ if Alex had heard correctly shouted back.

The caravan had departed Shiganshina with over a dozen wagons.

After the first clash with an advance party of freakishly fast titans, ‘abnormal’s’ as the caravan guards had referred to them as, the wagons had scattered in panic. Now only three remained, at least twenty people crammed into each.

Alex hoped the others had gotten away safely, and were now doing their best to make their way to Trost District.

The wooden gangplank beneath Alex and Billy jostled as the caravan banked to the right, the titan’s receding behind them.

“We’ll be OK” Alex said, setting a reassuring hand on Billy’s shoulder.

The gangplank shook again with a less then gentle jostle, its rear wheels seeming to bounce. It could have been a simple rock in the path, but to Alex it felt distinctly like an small earthquake.

It couldn’t have been the titan’s, they were still too far away.

Before Alex could think better of it, across the dividing fields the line of trees suddenly burst open, a fifteen metres tall titan smashing through the trees with uncharacteristic speed as it began running straight at the caravan.

“Fuck, an Abnormal!” the caravan master shouted, “Jenkin’s, lash the horse’s spines out. We’ve got an abnormal titan closing.”

“Oh God!” a woman cried.

The wagon bounced again, the driver’s whip lashing back and forth into the air as the horse chortled out their protests, the animals picking up speed as they galloped onwards

Across the field Alex could see the abnormal titan still sprinting towards them, its wiry misshapen limbs flailing left and right as its huge drooling jaws gnashed open and closed with a terrible wet crack, the colossal and naked humanoid continuing to close the distance with the wagons.

“We’re… we’re going to die” Billy whimpered.

Grasping at the wagons protective cover with one hand Alex twisted himself to one side, his head peeking out from the wagon’s rear edge. The farm the caravan master had just mentioned wasn’t far off, a small cluster of barns and workshops accompanied by a house. If Alex and Billy could just get inside one of the houses, find a cellar and…

“Oh Shit, more Titans!” Jenkins screamed.

They were just outside the farmhouse’s gate and the words had scarcely passed the drivers lips before Alex glimpsed the first titan. The ugly brute was small by the size of its kin, perhaps less than six metres tall. It rose up from behind one of the small workshop that dotted the edge of the farm, its meaty paw like hands clasped around the arm and leg of a screaming farmer whose abdomen it was still in the process of gnawing into. Thick human blood dribbled down its chin and chest.

The man’s howling screams echoed across the surrounding fields, Alex’s eyes widening in surreal fear as he saw the other titan emerge from amongst farmyard’s buildings.

The place was infested with them.

“Turn, Turn, Turn!” the caravan master was screaming.

It was at that moment that a small explosion shook the ground around them. The wagon’s rear wheels left the paved road beneath them, its occupants screaming in terror as the vehicle was pivoted to one side at the front, and then its anterior axel snapped. Alex was almost tossed clear even as the wagon came apart beneath him, the canvas hood ripping free as over twenty men, women and children were flung to the adjacent field.

Alex smacked straight into the dirt face first, the young boy all but somersaulting head over heels as he came to a pounding stop. Billy hit the ground just ahead of him, and ahead of the two boys the next wagon capsized, its occupants letting out a collective scream as they were hurtled free. The only wagon to survive the thunderous crash did not wait to try and help the passengers of its fallen companions, for whom it had no room for.

Rising shakily to his feet, Alex saw the last wagon speeding off, its driver lashing furiously as his horses as the sole surviving vehicle cart-wheeled itself around the edge of the farm, and then it was gone.

“Get up, Get up!” the caravan master screamed, rousing a woman and her daughter from the ground. Around the broken wagon the survivors from Shiganshina stumbled groggily to their feet, the bulk of them being women and small children, alongside a handful of labourers.

Already the titans inside the farm were taking notice of the refugees, and with an earth quaking crash that made the smaller children cry a ten-metre-tall titan was already clambering its way over the wall to get to them.

Alex didn’t wait to be eaten.

Rising unsteadily to his feet the boy leapt forward, grasping at Billy’s collar and pushing his brother forward.

“Get to the buildings!” the caravan master screamed, “There our only chance. Everybody Run!”

Alex and Billy were already running before the first titan had descended on the crowd, the gigantic humanoid grasping one of the caravan labourers up from the ground before crunching its think jaws into the man’s abdomen.

A high pitched human scream echoed outwards as the survivors scattered, Alex and Billy sprinting up towards the barn at the edge of the farm.

The sound of splashing water and mud accompanied by the tell-tale rapid quakes of approaching footfalls forced Alex to glance over his shoulder, his gut suddenly feeling hollow into his stomach. The abnormally fast titan vaunted across the final patch of field to crash straight into the overturned wagon, the fifteen-metre-tall monster grasping a woman from the fleeing crowd as it did so and all but ripping her into two bloody pieces in the process. Alex saw the caravan master charging the titan with a wooden baton over his shoulder, the young boy turning just in time to pull Billy up when his younger brother stumbled. A woman and three children had joined them, the six fleeing refugees now almost at the closest barn now.

Turning back to look over his shoulder, Alex glimpsed the titan swinging one of its malformed arms downwards, the caravan master flying backwards as his neck was broken.

A child screamed as more titan converged on those still cowering between the broken wagons, munching upon the old and young alike.

At the farms edge Alex and Billy finally made it to the barn, the woman and her children hot behind them. Together the six small humans made their way to the barn’s entrance, just as a second explosive quake rocked the farm.

The sudden shockwave rocked the clearing, almost sending Alex, Billy, the woman and children behind them tumbling to their knees. None of them had time to question the source of the explosive quake. They were just in front of barn’s two story double doors, a thick knot of iron chains wrapped around the wooden handles.

Alex pushed at the doors, but they would not open. The chains were secured by a heavy metal padlock and they wouldn’t budge.

“Oh God” the woman cried.

“Mommy look” one of the children said, gesturing towards the distance.

Alex forced his shoulder into the gates, but they still stubbornly refused to move.

He glanced around, looking for a shovel, and axe, anything that they may be able to force the doors open with.

“Alex, look!” Billy cried, his arm pointing towards the distance.

Before Alex could following his brother line of sight, the pallid and fleshy leg of a giant humanoid foot swung out from the other side of barn, the titan’s foot coming down to demolish a small tiled well with a miniature wake that shook the ground beneath Alex’s feet.

Alex grasped Billy’s shoulder and pulled his younger brother behind him, the woman doing the same with two of her children beside him. The titan was the abnormal one they had seen running across the field, fifteen metres tall and sporting an open wide toothed smile as it looked down upon the tiny humans with unmistakable intent.

Human screams of pain and death continued to echo across the farm that was quickly becoming a killing field for the feasting titans.

A dark shadow swept over the farm and surrounding countryside, neither Alex nor the mother realizing as they regarded the approaching giant with cold fear.

The titan was within arm’s reach of them now.

There was nowhere to run.

“Alex look” Billy said, tugging at his brother’s hand.

Alex turned his head to the horizon just in time to see an impossibly huge three toed alien foot descend to the ground, crushing the entire portion of the surrounding woodlands that seemed to encircle the farmland on that side.

An ear-splitting shockwave blasted over the entire farm.

Alex, Billy, the woman and her three children were all blasted back into the barns doors, the children screaming in terror as beside them even the titan was thrown from its feet and tossed backwards.

The air knocked from his lungs, Alex could only look upon the horizon in terror.

The woodland that had bordered the farm and its surrounding fields were gone, replaced by a veritable superstructure of a three toed alien boot. A handful of trees had survived the alien foot’s descent; trees that would have dwarfed even the fifty-foot-high titans were now dwarfed by the mere toes of this alien’s foot.

As the dust from the shockwave began to settle around the farm Alex looked up, his tongue suddenly dry inside his mouth. The vast alien foot that had all but obliterated the nearby forest was just the lower portion of a being much more massive in stature. A metallic sky-high cylinder rose upwards from the base of the foot, Alex’s eyes suddenly picking up another of the incompressibly huge cylinder like legs poised behind the first. The two legs met dizzyingly high above where the unmistakable silhouette of a woman stood, clad in a bizarre suit of full fitting alien armour and cloth that seemed to cling to her statuesque like form, almost like a glove. Her shape and stature were unmistakably alien, yet distantly human.

She blocked out the sky and sun a full mile above the tiny farm, her form dominating the horizon as far as Alex could lift his head.

“What is that?” Billy whispered.

**************************************************************************** **********************************************************************

Tali’Zorah’s first encounter with the so called ‘titan’s’ had been as one sided as he had been unsettling.

When she had first set foot upon this world, Tali had joked somewhat half-heartedly that she may well have been a giant upon this world for all the signs of civilization and geographical landmarks that she could see. That joke had seemed somewhat more plausible when she had encountered the ankle high protective wall, yet still Tali’s mind had persisted with the notion that there was some rational explanation for the situation she found herself in.

Her first encounter with the apparent indigenous inhabitants of this world had shattered that that persistent hope.

Humans!

Infinitesimal humans!

That was Tali’s first thought when she stumbled upon the first miniaturized humanoids, yet from her first glimpse of the islands indigenous inhabitants alone the Quarian knew something was dangerously wrong with the creatures aside from their tiny size.

They were pasty and ugly things, their naked misshapen bodies a grotesque parody of the humans she had gotten to know aboard the crew of the Normandy, and beyond. Some were significantly taller than their fellow humanoids, and others much smaller than their companions. Some had terribly misshapen limbs, whilst others sported bizarrely shaped heads upon torsos too small to adequately support their bobbing heads. None could have been more then fifteen millimetres in height from the Quarian’s woman’s perspective, and many were a great deal tinier.

Tali had come upon her first such congregation of the tiny humanoids not long after she had encountered the wall. She had been half expecting them to scatter and run at her first approach, fleeing the armoured giantess in terror.

It was certainly what she would have done in their place.

Instead, the grossly misshapen humanoids had merely turned toward her, their wide-eyed faces and drooping jaws regarding the approach of the soaring Quarian woman in an almost zombiefied trance like state.

Curiosity had gotten the better of her.

Pausing above the tiny creatures Tali had reached down, her long gloved finger and thumb curling around one such titan as she lifted it from the ground.

“What are you…?” Tali had asked, the tiny humanoid prised not urgently between her finger and thumb. She had hoped for a response, some kind of compression from the minuscule creature even if it was only an acknowledgement of fear.

The titan was not entirely unresponsive.

The creature seemed to stir between the grip of her outstretched digits, its head twisting to an impossible angle as the bones it neck slurped and cracked, its head turning until it was facing the exposed surface of her thumb. Tali saw the creature jaws open, its white stubbly teeth glinting in the magnified view of her visored helmet, and then it began to gnaw at the hard surface of her gloved thumb.

“Uuggg…disgusting!” Tali had cried.

A tiny warning light had flickered at the edge of her vision, informing her of the irritation to the surface of her environmental suit. Tali’s suit was armoured, with even the softest ‘padding’ of her clothing interlaced with weaved fibres of titanium and absorbent gels, but the act alone was repulsive enough.

Without consciously thinking about it, Tali clenched her finger and thumb together, slowly crushing the fifteen-millimetre-tall humanoid between the space of her digits until only bloodied flesh and broken bones remained.

Still somewhat disgusted by the experience, Tali had been about about to reach down towards the utility belt at her waist to pull free an antiseptic wipe when she suddenly remembered the other tiny humanoids still beneath her. She had been so engrossed with the one in her hand, Tali and not taken notice of the other tiny humanoids congregating around her feet, and now at least a dozen were busy gnawing at the base of her boots. There were at least a dozen of them, and more approaching

“You little bosh’tet’s” Tali almost screamed, “Get away from me…!”

She lifted her foot, the movement alone knocking over at least half of the little pests. Her hands clenching to fists at her sides, Tali flexed her colossal dual toes above the titans, any suspicion at the back of her mind that these pests were humans that had somehow found themselves micronized being quietly quashed.

Tali brought her foot down on the offending humanoid bugs with a violent stomp, her boot sinking into the soft ground almost to her ankle. She felt the tiny humanoid forms beneath the hard surface of her foot popping and squishing beneath her sole.

Their companions didn’t get the hint, continuing to bite and gnaw at the surface of Tali’s other boot. They were subsequently the next ones Tali crushed, this time beneath the hard surface of her toes.

It was like stepping on starved scuttleroaches, the type of insects that infested starships and could never be exterminated quickly enough.

As a rule, Quarian’s detested insects of all forms. Insects carried diseases, pilfered food stores, used up valuable oxygen supplies and ate through starship cabling. No Quarian suffered an insect to live in their sleeping quarters, home or ship, and it was with exactly this loathing hatred that Tali came to view the titans after her first encounter.

They were little more than bugs to her, and any more that Tali happened to find in her path, she made a special effort to crush beneath her boots.

Despite her initial revulsion, something about the titan’s presence still unsettled Tali and it was not their disgustingly zombie like state of intelligence.

That wall had been built for a reason, and whoever had constructed it must have had a more than basic grasp of engineering and mathematics, and thus an above adequate level of intelligence. Even as she thought about it and recalled the dimensions of the miniature wall, Tali realized that the oddly proportioned and misshapen titans were several times to large to make adequate use of the gatehouses, towers and other fortifications along the wall. In fact, everything Tali had observed of them so far made it abundantly clear that the titan’s could not have constructed the wall themselves.

So, who had?

It was perhaps after another full hour of fruitless walking, her feet aching that Tali came upon her second sign of civilisation. She had been walking through a forested region, the great trees little more than blades of neatly cut grass to her when she glimpsed the tiny reflection of sunlight.

At the centre of the forest where a small clearing had been made a tiny cluster of buildings stood, the tiny hamlet surrounded by what Tali quickly realized were finally cultivated fields divided neatly by their own insignificantly small fences and stone walls.

It was a farm.

Tali altered her path, and within but a handful of steps she was virtually on top of the tiny farm, her foot descending to flatten a great portion of the woodlands that bordered the cultivated farmland beneath her armoured tread. She flexed her foot, her colossal dual toes sinking into the finally ploughed fields that surrounded the farm, each toe leaving a sunken crater wide enough to accommodate a dozen vehicles at least.

It occurred to Tali that she may have just unintentionally crushed a great deal of natural wildlife in the form of birds, rodents and antelope. Under normal circumstances this may have upset her deeply, but at this point in the day Tali really didn’t care what may have killed when she stepped down. She had yet to see any actual proof that creatures of actual intelligence still inhabited this galaxy forsaken island she now found herself upon.

Tali’s gigantic gloved hands found their way to her hips, and with an almost leisurely grace the Quarian cast eyes downwards towards the tiny farm at her boots. Light glinted off the faceplate of her oval visor, momentarily obscuring her sight. Tali gave her helmet a moment to adjust, and soon her visor was darkening, the image of the clustered barns and utility sheds that surrounded the single stone houses at the farms centre suddenly magnifying several times in size before her eyes.

There were tiny flickers of movement across the farmland, Tali’s lips curling in disgust beneath her visor at what she saw.

More Titans!

The place was infested with them, but something was different.

There were other humanoids down there, all of them significantly smaller than even the smallest titans, but unlike the bigger humanoids they were clothed.

The titans were eating them.

Blood, entrails and half gnawed and mutilated limbs were splashed across the farm like confetti. There were perhaps two dozen of the smaller humanoids as far as Tali could see, most of them inside the farm. For all intents and purposes they were almost identical to humans, with the exception of their almost microscopic size.

Whatever alien race these ‘humans’ really were, the larger naked titans were massacring them.

Clearly, they had been fleeing some kind of disaster judging from how unprepared they appeared, and these titans had set upon them, pinning them into the farm to been exterminated.

By the God’s{/i} Tali thought.

She must have over a mile tall from their perspective.

Tali was suddenly very aware of the very real nightmare she was in, as well as the spectacle her appearance had caused.

Down below the apparent massacre she had stumbled upon seemed to have paused, and Tali quickly realized that her last step had seem to cause a miniature earthquake to the tiny human’s and titans, toppling some and blasting the others back by the force of her footfall alone. Many of the almost microscopic humans seemed to regard her with fear, yet true to their earlier behaviour many of the titans seemed oblivious to her presence as they stumbled back to their feet to lumber after the tiny humans.

Under her visored helm Tali’Zorah nar Rayya pursed her lips together, unsure for the moment what she should do;

Chapter 0-2

24 Hours Earlier

Paradise Island

Fall of Shiganshina District (Wall Maria)


Fear, as powerful as it was raw hung over the human district of Shiganshina, southern most outpost of the kingdom that existed within the three walls.

Every street, alleyway and public space that was crammed into the modest outlier town was silent, the very human stench of terror chocking the throats of every single citizen who resided within that tiny pocket of humanity. All eyes were raised to the fifty metre high wall and the skinless yet very human like head that soared above it, a dark and unnatural shadow protruding across the centre of the district as the titan; colossal beyond all reckoning looked down upon the little humans with hunger.

Alex stared up at the giant’s head, his lips parted and mouth dry in the summer heat of the afternoon, the boy’s tongue stubbornly still and unmoving inside his mouth.

“Oh God…”

“It’s…it’s a titan” Sara whispered from behind him, the hand of his adopted sister clasped around his, her nails digging into his palm.

Movement flickered at the corner of his eye, and instinctively Alex knew that one of their two younger siblings was beside them.

Was it Billy, or Jessica?

Alex could not turn his head to see, so thawed with fear the young boy was.

Scarcely a minute before, the four young siblings had all been happy and laughing, the children enjoying the afternoon sunshine which had seen them relaxing in the central plaza of Shiganshina district.

They were homeless street orphans all of them, related neither by blood, marriage or money, but instead by the need of young children to find solace and comfort in a society that had all but abandoned them. Alex was the oldest of them at twelve years of age, with Sara the older ‘sister’ of the group at ten. Billy was eight, and Jessica six. They looked out for each other, protected each other, and together the four siblings formed a close knit family that survived together in the poorest region of the kingdom behind the walls.

That momentary happiness between the hunger, the freezing nights spent upon cold city streets and hiding from corrupt soldiers of the city garrison seemed a distant dream in Alex’s past now as the huge face of the titan looked down upon them.

“That’s…not possible…” Billy stammered, “…that wall is over fifty metres tall. That titan’s got to be…”

“Over Two Hundred feet high” Alex finished.

“Is that a titan?” Jessica asked, her voice as innocently naïve as it always was.

“We have to get out of…”

Before Alex could finish a thunderous crash shook the district, Wall Maria seeming to groan with the sound of cracking rock as the ground shook beneath the four children’s feet, and then the centre of the Curtain wall was smashed outwards in a churning explosion of dust and debris.

Alex was suddenly snapped from his stupor. Grasping his siblings by their arms he dragged them towards the nearest building as chucks of the broken wall peppered the city. Slabs of stone and mortar smashed through buildings, flattened houses and peppered streets, cutting down and crushing anyone unfortunate enough to find themselves in their path.

Blood splashed across the cobbled streets and walls as the first screams echoed across the district, fear giving way to panic as the full realization of what had just happened dawned upon the little township’s inhabitants.

“They’re though the walls!” someone screamed.

As he was helping Billy to his feet, Alex turned towards wall, his gut twisting like a knife inside his stomach. Wall Maria still stood, the Colossal Titan suddenly gone as quickly as it had appeared, but from the gaping hole it had smashed through the lower segment of the wall, lanky and pale humanoid forms many times taller than a man were emerging, gapping wide toothed mouths open atop bobbing listing heads, their swollen human like eyes searching hungrily for flesh.

Titans!

“We’ve got to get to the gate” Alex shouted, grasping Jessica’s arm as he did so, “Sara, take Billy’s hand. Don’t let go.”

“We’ve got no papers” Sara cried, “They won’t let us through.”

“We’ve got to try. Come On!”

Together, the four orphans sprinted across the open plaza, a large crowd already forming across the mouth of the Aquila thoroughfare, the most direct route to the only remaining gate out of Shiganshina District, and deeper into the Kingdom behind the Walls.

As they approached the avenue, just how hopeless their situation was becoming apparent to Alex very quickly. Shiganshina District contained over twenty thousand permanently resident men, women and children, and it seemed that every single one of them today was gathered into a single swelling crowd that blocked the main intersection of the thoroughfare, their numbers growing with every passing second.

A thin line of city guardsmen from the Royal Garrison were clustered around the baying mob, their distinctive blue trench coats marking them out amongst the crowd. Futilely they tried to bring some semblance of order to chaotic crowd, the militiamen burnishing their cumbersome bolt-action rifles into the air.

It was just as Alex and his three siblings reached the edge of the crowd that the sound of crumbling brick and masonry echoed across the open plaza. Panting for breath Alex turned, his three siblings pausing to follow his gaze towards the other end of the square, just in time to see a titan clambering over a triple storied house.

The titan was perhaps five or six metres tall, its giant form lurching drunkenly forward as it tried to navigate its way over the house, one long leg coming down upon the buildings balcony. The was a grinding off broken tiles and then suddenly the titan was plunging through the second storey roof, its arms flailing uselessly as it tried to dig its way free, and then the second titan appeared.

It was at least twice as tall of the first, and unlike its companion it emerged from the closest street, a third titan stumbling forth in its wake. More titans suddenly appeared, their slow unwieldy forms rising from behind the row of houses and shops that lined the plaza and adjacent roads, roofs and walls, an overhanging bridge collapsing as one smashed its way into the plaza, the tallest amongst them standing over fourteen metres high.

“There in the square!” someone shouted.

“Guardsman” shouted a thick voice, “Form Up. Deploy the howitzers!”

A line of guardsmen detached themselves from the crowd, running past Alex, Sara, Billy and Jessica as they stormed into the square. The tracked carriages of half a dozen matt-black howitzer cannons were pulled out with them, the soldiers forming a line about a hundred strong as they levelled their rifles and cannons towards the approaching titans. A thickly build man in a sergeants uniform emerged from their ranks. The man sported a curling moustache, and burnished a sword which he now swept through the air.

“Fire!” the sergeant screamed.

Alex clasped his hands over his ears, shouting at his siblings to do the same as the first volley fired, the whistling crack of close to a hundred rifles suddenly followed by explosive boom as the howitzers lets loose, the tracks of the heavy artillery guns lurching backwards with the force of the blast.

The rifle volley slammed into the oncoming titans, peppering their wiry misshapen bodies as the artillery rounds ripped through limbs, human like blood splashing across the plaza floor. Alex saw a titan stumble and fall, its nightmarish face reduced to a bloody stump where one of the howitzers had caught its head and ripped it clean off, but to his horror Alex could see its body already fighting to regain its footing, a twisting mass of flesh atop its neck already reforming as it head began to grow back.

No more than two of the titans had been felled by the solders first volley, and at least a dozen more were already shambling forwards, the closest halfway across the square already.

“Reload” the sergeant shouted, “Protect the civilians at all costs.”

The soldiers fired again, and the lead titan was cut down, but then another was shambling forwards in its place, its ten-metre-high form towering above the thin line of soldiers who were still reloading.

“What do we do!” Sara screamed from behind Alex, “We’re trapped.”

Alex turned back to the crowd, his heart sinking. Without the guardsmen there to police the evacuation, the crowd that still blocked the intersection had descended into an even more chaotic mass as people punched, kicked and clawed at each other, the press of so many human bodies preventing all but a handful from moving forward. Already Alex could see more titans worming their way around the plazas edge, and instinctively he knew they intended to flank the soldiers. The dumb brute’s tiny animal like minds had deduced the quickest possible path to the crowd.

That intersection would soon become a bloodbath.

“Alex!” Sara screamed, Jessica and Billy crying behind her “What do we do?”
